episodeTitle: The Target is Camie!! The Looming Clutches Of A Professional Kidnapper
description: The Straw Hats search for Rayleigh at Sabaody Park, where Camie fulfills her dream of riding the ferris wheel. Meanwhile, Zoro encounters a Celestial Dragon and narrowly avoids an international incident thanks to Jewelry Bonney's quick thinking. The episode ends with Camie being kidnapped by the slave trader Peterman.

events.title: Arrival at Sabaody Park
events.description: Luffy's group arrives at Groves 32-34, known as Bubbles Island, home to Sabaody Park. The crew begins their search for Rayleigh at the famous amusement park, though they quickly become distracted by the attractions and rides.
events.significance: Sets the stage for Camie's kidnapping and introduces the location where the dream of riding the ferris wheel will be fulfilled. The park represents a moment of joy before the arc's darker events unfold.

events.title: Camie's Dream Fulfilled: The Ferris Wheel
events.description: Camie fulfills her childhood dream of riding the large bubble ferris wheel at Sabaody Park. This dream is shared by most Fish-Men and Merfolk, who can only experience it at this mangrove due to the discrimination they face elsewhere. As a little mermaid, Camie would swim up to grove 13 and gaze at the sparkling lights in amazement.
events.significance: A poignant moment highlighting the discrimination against Fish-Men and Merfolk in the One Piece world. The ferris wheel represents freedom and dreams, making Camie's later kidnapping into slavery even more tragic. This joy-before-tragedy structure is classic One Piece storytelling.

quotes.text: I've always wanted to ride this ferris wheel! Ever since I was little!
quotes.speaker: Camie
quotes.context: Expressing her lifelong dream before riding the ferris wheel

events.title: Saint Charlos' First Appearance
events.description: Saint Charlos, a World Noble (Celestial Dragon), makes his debut. He encounters a critically injured man being rushed to the hospital by doctors, along with a nurse named Marie and her fiancé Judy. Charlos kicks the stretcher, causing the injured man to tumble to the ground, showing complete disregard for human life.
events.significance: Introduces one of the arc's primary antagonists and demonstrates the cruelty and absolute power of the Celestial Dragons. This scene establishes why attacking a World Noble results in Admiral dispatch and sets up the arc's climactic confrontation.

events.title: Marie and Judy's First Appearance
events.description: Marie, a nurse, and Judy, her fiancé, debut as they assist doctors carrying a critically injured man to the hospital. They are ordinary citizens caught in Saint Charlos' path.
events.significance: These characters serve to demonstrate the casual cruelty of the Celestial Dragons and the helplessness of ordinary people in their presence.

events.title: Saint Charlos Takes Marie as His Thirteenth Wife
events.description: Saint Charlos notices Marie and decides to take her as his thirteenth wife. When Judy objects and tries to protect his fiancée, Charlos casually shoots him without hesitation. The doctors and Marie are powerless to resist due to Charlos' status as a World Noble.
events.significance: Demonstrates the absolute power and cruelty of the Celestial Dragons. This act of casual violence against innocent people establishes the moral stakes of the arc and foreshadows why Luffy will eventually punch a Celestial Dragon. The shooting of Judy shows that human life means nothing to the World Nobles.

quotes.text: I'll take you as my thirteenth wife.
quotes.speaker: Saint Charlos
quotes.context: Claiming Marie despite her engagement to Judy

events.title: Zoro's Ignorance of World Nobles
events.description: Zoro stumbles upon the scene with Saint Charlos and the injured Judy. Unfamiliar with the World Nobles and their protected status, Zoro speaks to Charlos in his typical blunt manner, not showing the reverence expected. His ignorance of proper protocol angers the Celestial Dragon.
events.significance: Zoro's lack of knowledge about World Nobles nearly triggers an international incident. This establishes that the Straw Hats are still newcomers to the Grand Line's power structures and don't yet understand all the unspoken rules that govern the world.

events.title: Saint Charlos Shoots at Zoro
events.description: Enraged by Zoro's disrespectful attitude, Saint Charlos fires his gun at Zoro. Zoro easily dodges the shot and immediately prepares to counterattack, drawing his sword. For a moment, it appears Zoro is about to cut down a World Noble, which would trigger an Admiral dispatch.
events.significance: One of the most tense moments in the arc. If Zoro had successfully attacked Charlos, an Admiral would have been dispatched immediately, potentially leading to the Straw Hats' capture or death. This near-miss demonstrates how close the crew came to disaster through simple ignorance.

events.title: Jewelry Bonney Saves Zoro with Tomato Juice Trick
events.description: In the nick of time, Jewelry Bonney, one of the Eleven Supernovas, leaps at Zoro and tackles him to the ground. She calls him her 'brother' and splashes tomato juice on his forehead to make it appear he died from Charlos' gunshot. This quick thinking prevents Zoro from attacking the World Noble and stops an Admiral from being dispatched to the archipelago.
events.significance: Bonney's intervention saves not just Zoro, but potentially all the Supernovas present on the island. An Admiral dispatch would endanger everyone. This moment showcases Bonney's intelligence and her understanding of the World Government's protocols. It also establishes her as a morally complex character who, despite being a pirate, acts to prevent catastrophe.

quotes.text: Brother! No, my brother! He's dead! The World Noble's shot killed him!
quotes.speaker: Jewelry Bonney
quotes.context: Faking Zoro's death to prevent an international incident

events.title: Explanation of Admiral Dispatch Protocol
events.description: After the incident, Bonney explains to Zoro the dire consequences of attacking a Celestial Dragon. If anyone harms a World Noble in any way, the World Government automatically dispatches a Marine Admiral to hunt down and eliminate the perpetrator. This protocol ensures absolute protection for the descendants of the World Government's founders.
events.significance: Establishes one of the most important power dynamics in the One Piece world. The automatic Admiral dispatch protocol explains why Celestial Dragons can act with complete impunity and why even powerful pirates avoid confronting them. This information becomes crucial when Luffy later punches Saint Charlos, triggering Admiral Kizaru's arrival.

quotes.text: If you had attacked that World Noble, an Admiral would have been dispatched here immediately! You would have doomed us all!
quotes.speaker: Jewelry Bonney
quotes.context: Explaining the consequences to Zoro after saving him

events.title: Supernovas React to the Incident
events.description: Other members of the Eleven Supernovas witness or hear about Zoro's encounter with Saint Charlos. Urouge comments on the incident, saying 'I heard their crew's crazy.' The Supernovas recognize that the Straw Hats' reputation for recklessness has been reinforced, and Zoro isn't even the captain.
events.significance: Establishes the Straw Hats' growing reputation among their peers as the most reckless crew. This foreshadows Luffy's even more extreme action later in the arc. The comment about Zoro not being the captain hints that if Zoro is this bold, what will Luffy do?

quotes.speaker: Urouge
quotes.context: Commenting on the Straw Hats after Zoro's near-attack on a Celestial Dragon

events.title: Peterman's First Appearance
events.description: Peterman, the head of the Hound Pets kidnapping gang, makes his debut. He has been tailing the Straw Hats through Sabaody Park, having received information from bounty hunters that the crew is traveling with a mermaid. Peterman observes Camie from the shadows, planning his kidnapping operation.
events.significance: Introduces the episode's primary antagonist and sets in motion the kidnapping plot that will dominate the next several episodes. Peterman represents the dark underbelly of Sabaody Archipelago - the slave trade that thrives under the World Nobles' protection.

events.title: Camie is Kidnapped by the Hound Pets
events.description: While the Straw Hats are distracted at Sabaody Park, Peterman and the Hound Pets successfully kidnap Camie. They target her specifically because she is a mermaid, knowing she will fetch an extremely high price at the Human Auctioning House. The kidnapping happens off-screen while the crew is separated.
events.significance: This kidnapping is the catalyst for the arc's climax. It forces the Straw Hats to confront the slave trade directly and leads to Luffy punching Saint Charlos at the auction house. The kidnapping also demonstrates the danger merfolk face on Sabaody, where they are seen as valuable commodities rather than people.

events.title: Chopper Reports Camie's Kidnapping
events.description: Back at the Thousand Sunny, Chopper makes an urgent call to Sanji, Usopp, and Franky, reporting that Camie has been kidnapped. The crew at the ship realizes the severity of the situation but faces the challenge of locating Camie across the vast Sabaody Archipelago, which consists of 79 groves.
events.significance: The episode ends on this cliffhanger, setting up the rescue mission that will dominate the next episodes. The size of Sabaody Archipelago adds urgency - finding one mermaid across 79 groves will require the crew to work together and potentially seek help.

quotes.text: Camie's been kidnapped! We have to find her!
quotes.speaker: Tony Tony Chopper
quotes.context: Urgently reporting to the crew members at Sabaody Park

quotes.text: I've always wanted to ride this ferris wheel! Ever since I was little!
quotes.speaker: Camie
quotes.context: Expressing her childhood dream at Sabaody Park

quotes.text: I'll take you as my thirteenth wife.
quotes.speaker: Saint Charlos

quotes.text: Brother! No, my brother! He's dead! The World Noble's shot killed him!
quotes.speaker: Jewelry Bonney
quotes.context: Faking Zoro's death with tomato juice

quotes.text: If you had attacked that World Noble, an Admiral would have been dispatched here immediately! You would have doomed us all!
quotes.speaker: Jewelry Bonney
Urouge
quotes.context: Commenting on the Straw Hats after the incident

quotes.text: Camie's been kidnapped! We have to find her!
quotes.speaker: Tony Tony Chopper
quotes.context: Urgent call to crew about Camie's kidnapping

themes.description: Camie's dream of riding the ferris wheel represents the simple freedoms that Fish-Men and Merfolk are often denied due to discrimination and the threat of slavery. Her joy is juxtaposed against her kidnapping, emphasizing the precarious nature of freedom in a world with institutionalized slavery.
themes.symbolism: The ferris wheel symbolizes dreams and freedom, rising above the world below. For merfolk, this ride represents a rare moment of equality and joy in a world that often treats them as commodities.

themes.description: The episode starkly contrasts the absolute power of the Celestial Dragons with the powerlessness of ordinary people. Saint Charlos can kill, kidnap, and abuse without consequence, while others must bow and accept their fate or face Admiral dispatch.
themes.symbolism: Saint Charlos' bubble helmet symbolizes how the Celestial Dragons literally refuse to breathe the same air as 'commoners,' viewing themselves as gods above humanity.
culturalReferences: The Celestial Dragons parallel historical aristocracies and divine right monarchies, where nobility claimed godly status

themes.description: The episode confronts the dark reality of Sabaody's slave trade. Peterman and the Hound Pets represent the systemic kidnapping operation that supplies the Human Auctioning House, with merfolk being particularly valuable targets.
themes.symbolism: Sabaody Archipelago, the last stop before the New World, reveals the dark foundation of the World Government's power structure - a system that allows slavery to flourish under Celestial Dragon patronage.

themes.description: Zoro's ignorance of the World Nobles nearly causes catastrophe for all the pirates on Sabaody. The episode demonstrates how not understanding the world's power structures can have life-or-death consequences.

characterSpotlights.role: Victim whose joy turns to tragedy
characterSpotlights.development: Camie experiences the fulfillment of her childhood dream before being kidnapped into the slave trade. Her arc in this episode represents the vulnerability of merfolk in a world that commodifies them.
keyActions: Rides the ferris wheel at Sabaody Park, fulfilling childhood dream
Gets kidnapped by Peterman and the Hound Pets
quotes: I've always wanted to ride this ferris wheel! Ever since I was little!

characterSpotlights.development: Zoro's encounter with Saint Charlos reveals his lack of knowledge about the world's political structures. His near-attack on a Celestial Dragon demonstrates both his courage and his dangerous ignorance of consequences.
keyActions: Encounters Saint Charlos without knowing proper protocol
Nearly attacks a Celestial Dragon after being shot at
Gets saved by Jewelry Bonney's quick thinking
Learns about the Admiral dispatch protocol

characterSpotlights.development: Bonney demonstrates remarkable situational awareness and quick thinking by saving Zoro from himself. Her actions reveal her intelligence and her understanding of the World Government's systems.
keyActions: Recognizes the danger of Zoro attacking a Celestial Dragon
Tackles Zoro and fakes his death with tomato juice
Explains the Admiral dispatch protocol to Zoro
quotes: Brother! No, my brother! He's dead! The World Noble's shot killed him!
If you had attacked that World Noble, an Admiral would have been dispatched here immediately! You would have doomed us all!

characterSpotlights.development: Saint Charlos is introduced as a purely villainous character, demonstrating the cruelty and absolute power of the Celestial Dragons. His casual violence and disregard for human life establish him as deserving of eventual comeuppance.
keyActions: Kicks over stretcher carrying critically injured man
Claims Marie as his thirteenth wife
Shoots at Zoro for being disrespectful
quotes: I'll take you as my thirteenth wife.

characterSpotlights.development: Introduced as the head of the Hound Pets, Peterman is established as a calculating professional kidnapper who targets Camie specifically for her value as a mermaid.
keyActions: Tails the Straw Hats through Sabaody Park
Coordinates Camie's kidnapping with the Hound Pets

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime expands the Sabaody Park sequence, showing more of the Straw Hats enjoying the amusement park rides and attractions. The manga covers this more briefly.
The anime adds more detail to Camie's ferris wheel experience, emphasizing her emotional reaction and childhood memories of gazing at the park from afar.

trivia.fact: Episode 393 aired during the period when One Piece omitted ending themes, a practice that lasted from episode 279 to episode 1070 (over 17 years).
The opening theme 'We Are! (2008 Remix)' by TVXQ/Tohoshinki only lasted for 22 episodes (373-394), making it one of the shorter-lived opening themes in One Piece history.

Jewelry Bonney's tomato juice trick to save Zoro is an anime/manga-original scene that doesn't appear in earlier One Piece databooks, making it a unique moment in the series' portrayal of pirate cooperation.
Saint Charlos is voiced by Chafurin in Japanese, who is known for voicing brutal and villainous characters in anime. His performance emphasizes Charlos' cruelty.
The ferris wheel at Sabaody Park is made of large soap bubbles, consistent with the archipelago's unique ecosystem where the Yarukiman Mangrove trees produce special resin bubbles.
This episode covers only one manga chapter (Chapter 499), but expands the content significantly to fill the 22-minute runtime.
